content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting , planning meeting is starting now!

(sorry, I meant to send out a reminder like 40 minutes ago, and then I got distracted by trying to recreate the debuginfo issues I was complaining of yesterday because I thought we might need a steering meeting about debuginfo.)
(really we still might need a steering meeting about debuggers, but I’m not ready to float a proposal there yet, not on this cycle.

Let start off with five minutes for

Announcements

• (sort of an announcement) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/83027 could use some eyes, as it's a performance regression in beta. not yet triaged to the point where discussion makes sense though --- would wait until regular meeting, but we're a little short on time
FYI: I couldn't reproduce it.
Hmm
So should we try to get an owner on #83027 today
or leave it open for anyone to try to snag for a little bit
@simulacrum I’ll put an event in my calendar for … either today … or Monday… to circle back around to #83027 and see if anyone has taken ownership of it yet. Does that sound okay to you?
yeah that sounds good
okay. So lets look at the proposal list
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Ameeting-proposal+-label%3Ameeting-scheduled
five proposals. Two old, three new
Lets quickly talk about the two old ones first

• (recurring) regression day aka compiler-team#401
  • perf triage report construction aka compiler-team#400
@simulacrum I think we’ve determined that a regression day is best structured as a targetted meeting with the leads and either you or other reps from T-release. Does that sound accurate?
yes, that sounds accurate
we can likely close the issue
Sounds great
The only action item
I'm expecting to schedule those as needed by pinging you/Wesley
would be to document that part of our overall process
and be ready to plan ahead for those meetings
right?
Okay, schedule as needed
I guess that makes sense too
(crater run is variable end date so hard to get a concrete thing on schedule I think)
Is @rylev around?
The only reason why I ask
is that I could go either way on whether to try to schedule a meeting for compiler-team#400
@rylev has put a fair amount of effort into describing the current system, and proposing tweaks to it
the question is whether we’re at a stage where a steering with the team would be useful or not

@simulacrum since you are also involved in performance-triage process, do you have an opinion there? Should we table scheduling that meeting? (Should the issue be closed at this point, until a broader proposal is put forward?) Or should we have a meeting just to try to force eyeballs on what @rylev has written?
I... don't really have an opinion
I think change is hard :)
I'd probably table it for now
Okay. In the interest of making forward progress right now
let just table it
as in, we won’t put it up for potential scheduling this cycle
but I won’t close it yet either. I’d want to talk to @rylev before doing that.
So that leaves the new stuff!
three items

• compiler-team#412: memshrink sprint retrospective
  • compiler-team#415: dylibs need directors
  • compiler-team#416: static vs dynamic linking defaults for MUSL targets
and, the timeline we’re talking about, is the next three fridays
19 March, 26 March, 2 April
Keeping in mind that the next Rust release is on 25 March
So, I think retros are a great idea, I would vote for compiler-team#412
Given that we just had the sprint, I think it would be good to do the retro as soon as reasonably possible before we forget anything important.
Right. I suspect biasing towards “soon so we don’t forget” vs “wait so we have more time to reflect” is absolutely right call
I'm not sure that compiler-team#415 will be solved by a meeting-- maybe
Well
I suppose it wouldn’t have to be synchronous
It seems like it also needs a bit of outreach to find those directors who would prepare the doc that the issue describes :)
getting eyeballs on the description of the problems is itself important
that's true
to confirm/deny that description
At the least, 415 doesn't seem urgent as that has been the status quo for years. Since there's interest/activity in 416, I think it would be good to schedule that one next.
but without the description itself, it may be premature
I agree with @Wesley Wiser about urgency, but I also think @pnkfelix you've got a good point that a logical starting point would be to establish the motivation and problems
I suspect a sync meeting is the wrong tool for that though

nikomatsakis said:

It seems like it also needs a bit of outreach to find those directors who would prepare the doc that the issue describes :)

Indeed. One of my hopes sitting here now was to see if anyone present would like to volunteer to investigate it.
I remember some of the GNOME folks raising this years ago
and having quite strong arguments in favor of us doing more around dylibs + stable ABIs
(it came down to: the cost to recompile things is non-trivial at scale, and it's not practical to do that every 6 weeks)
better dylib handling would also be nice for the cg_clif jit mode.
We also have some guests that are interested in participating in the MUSL discussion. Perhaps we should make sure one of the two proposed dates (26 March or 2 April) work for them?
I would favor tabling for now but I think if we could find someone to organize at least like survey / thread / documenting motivations, it'd be a good starting point
what is current relationship between Microsofft and GNOME?
@Wesley Wiser why not 19th?
I believe that's @Rich Felker, @Ariadne Conill and maybe @Érico Nogueira Rolim?
Yes, for 416, I was told you're looking for input from outside stakeholders (musl, affected distros, ...?)

pnkfelix said:

what is current relationship between Microsofft and GNOME?

(i ask this because I’m curious whether there are resources at Microsoft that coul be put towards the issues raised by GNOME that @nikomatsakis noted above.)

what is current relationship between Microsofft and GNOME?

I'm not sure there is one or why there would be.

Wesley Wiser said:

I believe that's Rich Felker, Ariadne Conill and maybe Érico Nogueira Rolim?

This is list of stakeholders in compiler-team#416, right?

Wesley Wiser said:

what is current relationship between Microsofft and GNOME?

I'm not sure there is one or why there would be.

I guess I make in a connection in my head with GNOME -> Miguel de Icaza -> Mono -> .NET -> Microsoft
its quite a stretch
looking
Ah, gotcha. I don't really know anything other than I believe Miguel hasn't really been involved with GNOME for a decade or more at this point.
yeah, might as well reach out to Linus Torvalds. Or Kevin Bacon. based on chain I put up above.
I don't see a list of stakeholders on the issue. So far you have maintainer (me) and reps of two of the biggest musl-based distros.
Sorry, my question was not clear
I was just trying to understand context of @Wesley Wiser ’s remark
when I brought up stakeholders
Oh sorry
:rofl: Kevin Bacon. :rofl: You're killing me here.

So I talked to @Ariadne Conill yesterday about 416 and they asked if they could invite a few other stakeholders from the Linux distro/MUSL communities who would like to participate in that discussion.
Do we think we can make reasonable decisions about compiler-team#416 even if we table compiler-team#415 ?
That sounds good to me.
Thanks @Rich Felker and @Érico Nogueira Rolim for joining us! :smile:

pnkfelix said:

Do we think we can make reasonable decisions about compiler-team#416 even if we table compiler-team#415 ?

(I suspect we can, though it seems very weird to try to move forward without established owners of the dylib topic itself.)
I don't see hor 415 and 416 are highly related
415 is about dylib crates, not whether the default link mode for a target is dynamic, no?
I also don't see a huge relation between the topics.
/me looks
Perhaps my meeting title was poorly worded
No I see, I should have read the summary more carefully
416 is basically just about whether or not the default for -musl targets is to statically link libc or dynamically link it.
I would expect the group coming out of 415 to look at stuff like https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/82912 though
and the repercussions of that decision on our current targets
Yes

Rich Felker said:

I would expect the group coming out of 415 to look at stuff like https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/82912 though

ooh I should add those links from @Vadim Petrochenkov to the reading list for compiler-team#415
okay then, I agree that 415 and 416 seem orthogonal
so lets table 415 for this cycle. (But if anyone is interested in helping to write an initial document, priv msg me. Maybe I’ll try twitter again for this.)

Wesley Wiser said:

and the repercussions of that decision on our current targets

Targets and documentation, since there is at least one official page about using the musl target as an exclusively statically linked one to ship self contained binaries (without having to export RUST_FLAGS or some such).
Since it seems like compiler-team#416 potentially has more scheduling constrants, lets schedule it first
OK
I take it that @Ariadne Conill is not present at moment. Does anyone know their schedule?
(in terms of which, if any, of the dates above work for them?)
I'm pinging @Ariadne Conill on irc
(to be clear: the usual time for these meetings is the same time slot that we’re in right now)
Thanks @_Rich Murphey @Rich Felker
No, they didn't give me any preferred dates.

Érico Nogueira Rolim said:

Wesley Wiser why not 19th?

To answer this Q: I assume @Wesley Wiser was implicitly reserving the 19th for the retrospective. (But I don’t think we need to do that. I’d rather accommdate guests from outside T-compiler.)
Yes, but I don't feel strongly
@Rich Felker what is your availabilty for this hour timeslot on 19 Mar vs 26 Mar vs 2 Apr ?
(and same Q for @Érico Nogueira Rolim )
They should all be equivalent for me; this time's generally non-conflicting
Assuming things on Mar 19 move very fast, that would allow the release on Mar 25 to include a warning about upcoming changes, but I don't know how this stuff usually works.
And yes, all dates are mostly the same for me.
That's a good point
the meeting date seems orthogonal from the date of making changes

Érico Nogueira Rolim said:

Assuming things on Mar 19 move very fast, that would allow the release on Mar 25 to include a warning about upcoming changes, but I don't know how this stuff usually works.

You mean a warning in the release notes?
unless there is a time pressure that requires making them faster
(Or a programmatic warning?)
In any case, I suspect planning on deploying the results of a decision from the 19th in time for the release on the 25th is … not great planning

nikomatsakis said:

unless there is a time pressure that requires making them faster

I guess I’m just echo’ing Niko here.

Well I think more importantly, if we decide we need to change the existing targets, we always have the option of announcing that in a dedicated post to blog.rust-lang.org separate from any given release.
@Wesley Wiser what kind of write-up do we need ahead of time for the meeting, do you think? Does the issue from @Ariadne Conill serve well enough, or should we have a separate writeup?
Sorry, which issue?
for compiler-team#416, yeah
I’m basically trying to incorporate that question into the question of when to schedule it
I wrote that based on my limited understanding of the current plan

pnkfelix said:

(Or a programmatic warning?)

I really don't know, to be honest. I believe Rust occasionally does things like deprecate types in some stdlib or similar before some change (I'm thinking of time_t on 32-bit musl platforms here), and that generates a programmatic warning. But I don't have nearly enough experience in the Rust environment to know what the correct way forward is.
I suspect we need a more fleshed out write-up than what we have: something that would be digestable at the outset of the meeting

I think going into the meeting it would be good to have a better writeup detailing the (I believe) two potential options we have, the pros/cons to both and what questions need to be resolved to decide which path is viable.
which leads me to think that trying to schedule it for 19 March would be a mistake
unless we have someone on board to start trying to make a writeup now
I agree that a meeting on the 19th and a release on the 25th incorporating changes from it would be very close together, so there isn't a rush to include things.
FWIW I think a lot of that data is in the PR thread but there is quite a bit of discussion in that PR and it can be difficult to follow all of the conversation threads.

pnkfelix said:

unless we have someone on board to start trying to make a writeup now

(of course the counter-argument to this point is: Why does Felix believe that waiting until later will magically solve the problem of not having someone to do the write-up)

Wesley Wiser said:

FWIW I think a lot of that data is in the PR thread but there is quite a bit of discussion in that PR and it can be difficult to follow all of the conversation threads.

Right: I’m hoping that the bulk of the writeup will be condensing what has already been said and following those threads, vs having to do any novel research/design work.

I do not mind investing more time into doing that and I would love to see this situation resolved for everyone but I'm not sure I have enough free time between now and next Friday to do a good job and ensure we have a productive meeting.
anyway, knowing that releases can sometimes steal time, I’m tempted to say we should schedule compiler-team#416 to 2nd April
because its possible no one here will have any free time up until 25th March
How does 2 April sound to @Rich Felker and @Érico Nogueira Rolim ?
(This way, we can be somewhat assured that we’ll have time for the writeup. At the cost of waiting longer for the meeting and thus a decision.)

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

FWIW I think a lot of that data is in the PR thread but there is quite a bit of discussion in that PR and it can be difficult to follow all of the conversation threads.

Right: I’m hoping that the bulk of the writeup will be condensing what has already been said and following those threads, vs having to do any novel research/design work.

Do you have an example of what a write up would look like? If @Ariadne Conill doesn't have the availability for it, I can try my hand. I have an idea of the overall landscape and have read through most of the issues / PRs.
april 2 is the friday before easter I think?
/me is not used to holidays being on non-mondays
You’re right, thaxt’s Good Friday

Érico Nogueira Rolim said:

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

FWIW I think a lot of that data is in the PR thread but there is quite a bit of discussion in that PR and it can be difficult to follow all of the conversation threads.

Right: I’m hoping that the bulk of the writeup will be condensing what has already been said and following those threads, vs having to do any novel research/design work.

Do you have an example of what a write up would look like? If Ariadne Conill doesn't have the availability for it, I can try my hand. I have an idea of the overall landscape and have read through most of the issues / PRs.

@Érico Nogueira Rolim I would be happy to work with you on that especially if that means we can schedule the meeting sooner!

pnkfelix said:

You’re right, thaxt’s Good Friday

okay, so scratch April 2nd
In that case, lets go for 26th March then
(I’d rather risk last minute release stuff stealing tme than just knowing that one week to prep makes it more likely that meeting will be bad.)

Wesley Wiser said:

Érico Nogueira Rolim said:

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

FWIW I think a lot of that data is in the PR thread but there is quite a bit of discussion in that PR and it can be difficult to follow all of the conversation threads.

Right: I’m hoping that the bulk of the writeup will be condensing what has already been said and following those threads, vs having to do any novel research/design work.

Do you have an example of what a write up would look like? If Ariadne Conill doesn't have the availability for it, I can try my hand. I have an idea of the overall landscape and have read through most of the issues / PRs.

Érico Nogueira Rolim I would be happy to work with you on that especially if that means we can schedule the meeting sooner!

Over which channel would this be?

Érico Nogueira Rolim said:

Over which channel would this be?

We usually do it over text
much like this
but we can also do zoom
(or jitsi ; @oli used that well recently)
We’re at the hour
We can PM on Zulip or work out of a hackmd.io or even just a GH issue or something.
but I think we’ve made a rough consensus
I can own compiler-team#412 memshrink retrospective for 19 March, and @Wesley Wiser can own compiler-team#416 for 26 March
and I can make an Inside Rust blog psot
saying so
only thing I’d like to figure out is whether it will indeed be just on zulip, or if we’ll use video chat for any ofit
lets maybe take a quick straw poll here
I prefer text chat but can do either
If you want meeting in zulip, put :flower: emoji. If you want meeting in zoom/jitsi , put :video_camera: emoji. If you don’t care, put :shrug:
(I suspect we’ll defaut to Zulip unless we see a push to do video)
Okay, great meeting everyone! Thanks to @nagisa for pointing out real life scheduling concerns! and thank to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

Wesley Wiser said:

We can PM on Zulip or work out of a hackmd.io or even just a GH issue or something.

Ok, I will hit you up via PM later today so we can sort it out! I will try to reach @Ariadne Conill to see if there's anything already being worked on too.
Great, thank you! :smile:
To clarify - that 26 Mar meeting would be at the same time? (10 GMT-5)
@Max Rees sae time as this meeting, yes
To use the fancy Zulip feature, todays meeting was at 2021-03-12T10:00:00-05:00 and other meetings will be at that same time.
alright cool. my alarm failed to go off
that date works for me
does Zulip have PM groups? or perhaps we can just do a hackmd.io and share it publicly amongst interested participants

Ariadne Conill said:

does Zulip have PM groups? or perhaps we can just do a hackmd.io and share it publicly amongst interested participants

I would prefer a public stream, and maybe have a hackmd you link in the stream

pnkfelix said:

simulacrum since you are also involved in performance-triage process, do you have an opinion there? Should we table scheduling that meeting? (Should the issue be closed at this point, until a broader proposal is put forward?) Or should we have a meeting just to try to force eyeballs on what rylev has written?

I would really, really like to continue making progress on this. I'm basically just waiting for others to have any free cycles to engage with the ideas I've written down. Change is hard, but I'd like for us to at least try some improvements. The ideas in the document are by no means all or nothing. We can do this incrementally.
(sorry for not being around - my calendar didn't show this meeting for some reason)

rylev said:

(sorry for not being around - my calendar didn't show this meeting for some reason)

that’s weird. Let me know if its a recurring issue in your calendar. The meeting calendar link looks correct to me, but that doesn’t mean its interoperating properly for everyone.
